Scheme 1 The catalytic transformation of MBDO to isoprene with UOLs as the intermediate. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Speculative reaction mechanism of MBDO dehydration to isoprene. (a) Dehydration of MBDO to 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol; (b) followed by the formation of isoprene; (c) dehydration of 3-methyl-3-buten-1-ol to isoprene; (d) decomposition of 3-methyl-3-buten-1-ol to isobutene. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 TG profiles of as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples aged for 0 (a), 1 (b), 2 (c), 4 (d), 24 (e), 72 h (f), and Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst with HT aging time of 0 h (g). Fig 1 Fig. 2 TD-MS signals of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 sample with HT aging for 24 h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 The specific surface area of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 and Y2Zr2O7-900 (A) and the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts (B) with different HT aging times. Reaction temperature, 300 °C; W/F = 0.31 h; carrier gas flow rate, 3000 cm3 h−1. Fig 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of (A) as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples after being aged at various HT aging times and (B) their Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TPD profiles of CO2 (A) and NH3 (B) adsorbed on Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts with different HT aging times. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Correlation between HT aging time with productivity, acidity (a), and basicity (b) of Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst shown in Table S2. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst at reaction temperatures of 300 (A) and 400 °C (B). HT aging time, 24 h; W/F = 0.31 h. Fig 7 Fig. 8 The effect of reaction temperature at W/F = 0.31 h (A) and contact time, W/F (B) on the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst. HT aging time, 24 h. Fig 8 Fig. 9 The stability of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst calcined at different temperatures at a reaction temperature of 350 °C (A) and Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst at different reaction temperatures (B). Others included some unidentified products. b Included 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran (1.4), methanol (0.5), 3M31 (3.1), and 2M32 (10.8), etc. c Included 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran (31.6), methanol (6.5), 3M21 (5.5), and 2M32 (0.6), etc. d Included 3-methylbutyl 3-methylbutanoate (20.3), 3-methylbutanal (2.2), and isopentane (0.2), etc. e Included 3-methyl-2-butanone (14.4), and isopentane (0.3), etc. Selective formation of isoprene via dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst Ryo Kobayashi Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft Enggah Kurniawan Visualization Writing – review & editing Yasuhiro Yamada Supervision Validation Satoshi Sato Conceptualization Methodology Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Chiba University, 1-33 Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Chiba University 1-33 Yayoi, Inage Chiba 263-8522 Japan Chiba University, 1-33 Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol to produce isoprene was investigated over Y2Zr2O7 catalysts prepared by hydrothermal aging at 200 °C with various aging times. Removal of residual species such as nitrate and crystallization of Y2Zr2O7 proceeded during the hydrothermal aging. The X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the progression of the Y2Zr2O7 crystal growth during hydrothermal aging from 0 to 24 h, with no significant change afterward. The hydrothermal aging time of up to 4 h significantly influenced the acid-base properties of the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts, which consecutively affected their catalytic performance. At a reaction temperature of 375 °C, the conversion of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol and the selectivity to isoprene over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst calcined at 900 °C were 100 and 82.4% at a time on stream of 10 h, respectively. Reaction mechanisms were also proposed in consideration for the results of dehydration of intermediate unsaturated alcohols. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Isoprene 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol Dehydration Hydrothermal aging Y2Zr2O7 Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Isoprene is an important chemical used in synthetic rubbers [1,2], resins [3], and fragrances [4], and it is mainly produced by naphtha cracking [5,6]. This process is heavily relied on depleting fossil fuels and has been known as an energy-intensive process [7]. Furthermore, with the rise of global concern due to the environmental problem associated with the utilization of fossil fuels [8,9], the production of isoprene through naphtha cracking poses long-term problems. On the other hand, extensive studies have been dedicated to upgrading renewable and abundant biomass to produce various value-added chemicals that are commonly generated from fossil fuels [10–12]. Lignocellulosic biomass, in particular, has been considered a promising feedstock, with numerous potential routes to generate many platform compounds such as 5-hydroxymethylfurufural, furfural, polyols, organic acids, and nitrogen-containing chemicals, i.e., amino acids [13,14]. Due to this reason, catalytic technology for biomass transformation to isoprene is highly desired due to its promising sustainability. The production of isoprene via catalytic dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol (MBDO) aligns with the effort to alleviate fossil fuel consumption in producing value-added chemicals. MBDO could be derived from biomass-derived isobutene (IB) and formaldehyde via Prins reaction. IB can be obtained from bio-ethanol conversion [15] and biological fermentation [16], while formaldehyde can be generated from lignin acidolysis [17] and partial oxidation of methanol [18]. Due to its origin, MBDO offers a greener and more promising sustainability for catalytic transformation to generate numerous value-added chemicals than the conventional route originating from fossil fuel. Catalytic dehydration of polyols is among essential organic transformation used to produce chemicals such as amino acids [13], unsaturated alcohols [19] and dienes [20,21]. The formation of dienes, in particular, has been extensively studied due to the high economical value of dienes in rubber and polymer industries [22]. Numerous reports have shown that solid acid catalysts are active for dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene [23–28]. For example, Pera-Titus et al. have reported the production of butadiene from 1,3-butanediol with a yield of ca. 60% over Al-doped SBA-15 catalyst [25]. Meanwhile, Lee and Hong employed several zeolites as catalysts for 1,3-butanediol dehydration and found out that high-silica H-ferrierite gave the highest butadiene yield with the highest durability among several zeolites tested [27]. It is worth noting that in both reports the production of a by-product propylene with the yield of 10–30% reduces the butadiene yield. We have also reported some catalytic strategies to convert butanediols to butadiene using rare earth metal oxide as catalysts [20,21,29,30]. Our studies showed that rare earth metal oxides possess tunable acid-base and structural properties that can be adjusted by hydrothermal (HT) and calcination conditions: several catalytic strategies have been successfully developed for the production of butadiene from butanediols. Even though numerous reports have shown potential route of obtaining diene from diol, the catalytic strategy for direct production of isoprene from MBDO via dehydration is rarely reported. A recent work by Bai et al. showed the production of isoprene with a yield of 73% via dehydration of 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol over CeO2 catalyst [31], which showcased the possibility of isoprene production via dehydration of diols. Recently, a series of dehydration of 1,3- and 1,4-butanediols has been successfully carried out over yttrium zirconate (Y2Zr2O7) catalyst to produce butadiene with the yield of 90% or higher, while the yield of by-product propylene is less than 2% [32,33]. The high activity of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst during butanediol dehydration was related to its high crystallinity and surface area, which are affected by HT aging and calcination conditions. Moreover, the oxygen-defect cubic fluorite structure of Y2Zr2O7 provided an efficient adsorption site during butanediol dehydration. In an analogy to the 1,3-butanediol dehydration, the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst possesses some catalytic properties that could potentially be utilized for MBDO dehydration to produce isoprene. In this work, we reported the vapor-phase dehydration of MBDO to isoprene over the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst. The effect of HT aging time and calcination temperature on the structural properties of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst was elaborated by use of adsorption analyses. In addition, some catalytic parameters such as reaction temperature and contact time were also investigated to determine the optimum conditions for catalytic dehydration of MBDO to isoprene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zirconyl nitrate dihydrate (ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O) and yttrium nitrate hexahydrate (Y(NO3)3·6H2O) with a commercial grade were available from Fujifilm Wako Chemicals, Co., Japan and Sigma-Aldrich, Co., U.S., respectively. CeO2 as a reference catalyst was supplied by Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co., Ltd. The Y2Zr2O7 catalyst was prepared by HT aging method, as reported previously [32–34]. Typically, the desired amount of ZrO(NO3)2·2H2O and Y(NO3)3·6H2O were loaded into a Teflon container and dissolved with 50 cm3 of distilled water. An aqueous ammonia (25 wt.%, 10 cm3) was added dropwisely to the solution under vigorous stirring to obtain a white slurry. The slurry together with the mother solution was aged in a steel jacket with 100 cm3 of Teflon container at 200 °C for a prescribed time. The resulted slurry sample was washed by centrifugation with distilled water three times and dried at 110 °C for 15 h. The dried sample is called an as-prepared sample. Afterward, the dried sample was calcined at a prescribed temperature for 3 h. The resulting catalysts are expressed as Y2Zr2O7-T, where T represents the calcination temperature (°C). Other heavy rare earth zirconates (RE2Zr2O7) such as Dy2Zr2O7, Ho2Zr2O7, Er2Zr2O7, and Yb2Zr2O7 were prepared in the same manner as described above. In addition, Y2O3-900 (specific surface area, SA = 9.1 m2 g−1) was prepared at an HT temperature of 200 °C for 4 h by the same procedure as described above in the preparation of Y2Zr2O7 using only Y(NO3)3·6H2O solution; finally Y2O3 was calcined at 900 °C. Reference catalyst such as CeO2 (JRC-CEO-3, SA = 81 m2 g−1), zirconia (JRC-ZRO-3, SA = 94 m2 g−1), and γ-Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-7, SA = 195 m2 g−1) are supplied by Catalyst Society of Japan. A commercial amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 (grade 135, Si/Al ratio of 14.4, SA = 517 m2 g−1) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The thermogravimetry analysis (TG) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku). Prior to the measurement, a sample (ca. 10 mg) was heated in the air at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water on the sample. The sample was then heated from 110 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 to monitor its weight change. The thermal decomposition profile with mass analysis of thermally evolved gases (TD-MS) was recorded on BELCATII with BELLMASS unit (Microtrac BEL Corp.): a sample of 50 mg was heated in a helium flow of 50 cm3 min−1 from 110 to 775 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 after the sample had been heated in the helium flow at 110 °C for 1 h. The evolved gases were monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a quadrupole mass analyzer. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed by New D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) to identify the crystalline phase of the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts. The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis for the estimation of Y/Zr ratio in Y2Zr2O7 samples was performed by EDX-900HS (Shimadzu, Japan). The acid-base properties of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst were evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of adsorbed NH3 and CO2 using BELCATII (Microtrac BEL) equipped with a TCD detector: the detail procedure was described in the previous papers [29,34,35]. Prior to the adsorption of NH3 and CO2, the sample had been heated in a helium flow at 500 °C for 1 h. After the adsorption had been performed at 100 °C for 1 h, the desorption of NH3 and CO2 was monitored from 100 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The specific surface area of catalyst samples was determined by N2 adsorption at -196 °C using a self-made gas adsorption apparatus. The SA was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. 2.3 Catalytic test MBDO, 2-methyl-3-buten-2-ol, 3-methyl-3-buten-1-ol, and 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industries Co. Ltd., Japan. They were used for the catalytic reaction without further purification. The vapor-phase dehydration of MBDO was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow glass tube reactor. The catalyst at a weight (W) range between 0.35 and 3.0 g was loaded in the reactor tube and preheated in an N2 flow at the prescribed temperature for 1 h. The reactant MBDO was fed into the reactor at a liquid feed rate of F, F = 1.60 g h−1, together with N2 carrier gas containing 1% methane at the rate of 1800 cm3 h−1 unless otherwise noted. The catalytic reaction was performed at a temperature between 250 and 425 °C for a time on stream (TOS) of 5 or 10 h, and the liquid and gas effluents were recovered periodically every 1 h. The recovered products were identified using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a mass-spectrometer (QP5050A, Shimadzu) and a capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT, a length of 30 m, an inner diameter of 0.32 mm, GL-Sciences Inc., Japan). The liquid effluents collected in a trap at 0 °C were quantitatively analyzed by GC equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID-GC, GC-8A, Shimadzu) and a direct injection port with a 30-m capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT with an inner diameter of 0.53 mm, GL-Sciences) using 1-octanol as an internal standard. The gaseous products including isoprene were quantitatively analyzed by another FID-GC (GC-8A) with a 30-m capillary column (Inert Cap 5 with an inner diameter of 0.53 mm, GL-Science) using methane in the carrier gas as an internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dehydration of MBDO over RE2Zr2O7-900 Initially, we screened the catalytic activity of several RE2Zr2O7 catalysts for dehydration of MBDO since these zirconate catalysts were reported to be catalytically active for dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to produce unsaturated alcohols: 3-buten-2-ol, 2-buten-1-ol, and 3-buten-1-ol [34]. Table 1 summarizes the results of MBDO dehydration over five RE2Zr2O7-900 catalysts at a reaction temperature of 350 °C. In the present work, Lu2Zr2O7 catalyst was excluded due to its low catalytic activity in the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol [32]. Dy2Zr2O7 catalyst gave the highest isoprene selectivity; nevertheless, its selectivity rapidly decreased at 350°C and W/F = 0.31 h (Fig. S1). The major products were unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) such as 2-methyl-3-buten-2-ol, 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol, and 3-methyl-3-buten-1-ol under the conditions together with a noticeable production of IB (entry 1). Ho2Zr2O7, Y2Zr2O7, and Er2Zr2O7 catalysts showed similar isoprene selectivity (entries 2-4), with Y2Zr2O7 giving the lowest IB selectivity (entry 3). Among all the RE2Zr2O7-900 catalysts evaluated, the Yb2Zr2O7 catalyst possessed the lowest isoprene selectivity, despite having a high MBDO conversion (entry 5). In addition, CeO2, which is active for selective dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to form UOLs [21,36], was also active for the MBDO dehydration; however, the selectivity to isoprene was low (entry 6). Since the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst provided a high MBDO conversion and isoprene selectivity with the lowest IB selectivity, the Y2Zr2O7-900 was chosen as the catalyst for dehydration of MBDO to produce isoprene. In addition, Y is the least expensive of heavy rare earth metals evaluated. We have also performed the dehydration of MBDO over monometallic oxide of Y and Zr (entries 7 and 8). Both Y2O3 and ZrO2 were active for dehydration of MBDO; however, their catalytic performance was inferior to that of rare-earth zirconate catalysts (entries 1-5). It has been previously reported that solid acid catalysts were active for dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene [23–28]. Thus, the catalytic performance of solid acid catalysts such as Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 was investigated in the dehydration of MBDO (entries 9 and 10). Remarkably, both Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 gave higher MBDO conversion with higher isoprene selectivity than rare-earth zirconate catalysts at 300 °C. Nevertheless, the selectivity to IB was higher than the selectivity of isoprene. In fact, Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts generated IB with the highest selectivity among all catalysts evaluated in this work. These results indicate that solid acid catalysts, such as Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3, prone to facilitate side reaction, which consecutively hinder the formation of isoprene. It is also worth noting that ZrO2 and Al2O3 catalysts dehydrated MBDO to 3M31 with high selectivity, which is in good agreement with the previous report [37]. In addition to the IB formation, ZrO2, Al2O3, and SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts also gave a cyclic ether of 3M31 such as 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran as a major by-product. In Section 3.4, the IB formation from 3M31 is discussed, which further signifies the disadvantage of 3M31 formation during MBDO dehydration. 3.2 Effect of HT aging time The Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst was prepared by HT aging at 200°C with various HT aging times since it has been previously reported that high HT aging temperature was efficient in improving crystallinity of the resulted zirconate [33,34]. In addition to the HT aging temperature, we have recently found that the HT aging time is essential in removing undesired residues from the catalyst sample because these residues could affect the catalytic activity of the resulted catalyst by influencing its acid-base properties [35]. Fig. 1 shows the TG profiles of as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 and Y2Zr2O7 -900 samples with different HT aging times. The amount of weight loss at HT aging time of 0, 1, 2, 4, 24, and 72 h was 24, 20, 13, 11, 9, and 8%, respectively. The change of weight loss in TG curve suggests that longer HT aging time resulted in catalysts with less residues. It is worth noting that the change in weight in TG profiles (Fig. 1) was no longer observed at temperatures above 800 °C. The type of residues in the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 was investigated by TD-MS. Fig. 2 shows the TD-MS of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 with an HT aging of 24 h. The TCD signal of thermal desorption is comparable to the differential TG curve depicted in Fig. 1e. The mass analyzer detected H2O, NO, O2, CO, and CO2 at m/z = 18, 30, 32, 28, and 44, respectively. This indicates that residual species such as water, nitrate, and carbonate are present in the as-prepared sample even at an HT aging time of 24 h. Since the weight change in TG profiles was no longer visible at temperatures above 800 °C, it can be assumed that applying calcination temperature of 900 °C could efficiently remove these residues from the as-prepared catalyst. Fig. 3B shows the effect of HT aging time on the catalytic activity of Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts in the dehydration of MBDO at 300 °C. It is notable that the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst drastically increased as the HT aging time increased up to 24 h. However, further increment of HT aging time decreased the activity of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst even though Fig. 1 clearly shows that aging time longer than 24 h was more effective in removing the residues in the catalyst samples. Fig. 3A illustrates the effect of aging time on the specific surface area of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 and Y2Zr2O7 -900 samples. The specific surface area of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts was lower than that of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples. This phenomenon was due to the increment of the Y2Zr2O7 particle size after the as-prepared samples had been calcined at 900 °C [34]. Although the specific surface area of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 aged for 4 to 72 h was similar to one another, the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts showed a decline in catalytic activity as the HT aging time was prolonged from 24 to 72 h (Fig. 3B and Table S1). This finding suggests that the difference in the catalytic activity between the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst aged for 24 and 72 h was not caused by the change in specific surface area. Fig. 4A displays the XRD patterns of the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples. The peaks associated with cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7 intensified as the HT aging time was prolonged from 0 to 24 h, while no notable change was observed at HT aging for 24 and 72 h. This result indicated that the cubic fluorite crystallites of Y2Zr2O7 grew in the aqueous solution at 200 °C along with the increment of HT aging time up to 24 h. Therefore, the HT aging at 200 °C for 24 h was the most optimum conditions for the formation of the cubic fluorite crystallites of Y2Zr2O7. The as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples (Fig. 4A) were further calcined at 900 °C for 3 h. Fig. 4B shows the diffraction patterns of Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts with different HT aging times. The XRD patterns of Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts aged from 0 to 72 h showed no clear difference. The Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts had higher crystallinity than the as-prepared Y2Zr2O7 samples; therefore, calcination at 900 °C is essential in improving the crystallinity of the Y2Zr2O7 samples, in the same manner as the previous reports in the dehydration of butanediols [29,30]. Moreover, the SEM image in of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst in our previous report clearly showed that the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst composed of agglomerated-particles with a particles size between 30 and 50 nm [34]. Judging from the results in Figs. 3 and 4A, we can insist that the aging of precipitates of Y2Zr2O7 precursor promotes crystallization under HT conditions up to HT time of 4 h. It has been reported that yttria-zirconia crystallites are homogenized at 150 °C upon prolonging the HT time to 24 h [38]. Thus, the homogenization could be beneficial to generate acid-base sites and improve their consecutive catalytic properties. The homogenization processes of yttria-zirconia during HT aging might occur via two process i.e., dissolution/reprecipitation or solid state diffusion [38]. According to the results in the XRF analysis of Y2Zr2O7 -900 with different HT times, the ratio of Y/Zr of Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts with HT time of 0, 1, 2, 4, 8, 24, and 72 h were measured to be 1.11, 1.10, 1.08, 1.10, 1.08, 1.10, and 1.08, respectively. These Y/Zr values are similar to the reported yttria-zirconia which had the Y/Zr ratio of 1.07 [38]. The constant ratio of Y to Zr indicates that the homogenization during HT aging did not alter the ratio of Y to Zr. Although the dissolution/reprecipitation should involve significant crystal growth through Ostwald ripening, no significant crystal growth was observed after an HT time of 4 h (Fig. 4A), suggesting that the solid-state diffusion within each crystallite would be the dominant homogenization process. In addition to the homogenization, prolonging the HT time reduced the amount of residue of the as-prepared samples (Fig. 1) which would lead to better crystallization during calcination at 900 °C. The XRD patterns in Fig. 4A clearly show the growth of the cubic fluorite Y2Zr2O7 structure as the HT aging time was prolonged from 0 to 24 h. However, the XRD patterns cannot explain the decrement in the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts for the HT aging time longer than 24 h. Fig. 5 shows the CO2- and NH3-TPD profiles of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts aged at 200 °C from 0 to 72 h. The deconvolution of the CO2- and NH3-TPD profiles shown in Figs. S2 and S3 suggests the presence of acid and base sites with different strength. The acidity and basicity of Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts increased significantly along with the increment of HT aging time up to 4 h, followed by a slight changed afterward (Fig. 5 and Table S2). The substantial increment of the acid and base properties of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts for the initial 4 h of HT aging time was in good agreement with change in their SA (Fig. 3A). Thus, it can be assumed the change in acid-base properties of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts with HT time from 0 to 4 h was affected by the SA of the resulted catalyst. The SA of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts did not vary by prolonging the HT time from 4 to 72 h, leading to less substantial changes in acid and base properties. Previously, we have reported that 1,3- and 2,3-butanediol dehydration took place on acid-base concerted site of the catalyst [29,32]. The acid sites play a significant role for alcohol adsorption while the base sites are responsible for proton abstraction. The correlation between the HT aging time with productivity and acid-base properties of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalysts is depicted in Fig. 6 . The Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst with the HT aging time of 24 h provided the highest productivity of isoprene. Therefore, HT aging time of 24 h generated the most optimum acid-base ratio in the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst. The MBDO dehydration was a sequential process: (1) dehydration of MBDO to UOLs, and (2) dehydration of UOLs to isoprene. We have previously showed the plausible reaction mechanism of 1,3-butanediol to butadiene via a base-acid converted mechanism [32]. It is possible that the MBDO dehydration proceeds in a comparable manner to the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol. Initially, the OH group of MBDO is adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites (Zr4+ or Y3+) of the catalyst, followed by the abstraction of H atom as a form of proton with the surface basic sites of O2− to produce UOLs and water. In the following step, the OH of the UOLs is attached on the Lewis acid site of the catalyst. The basic site of surface O2− abstracts the H atom from UOLs to generate isoprene and water. The plausible reaction mechanism of 1,3-butanediol indicates that a single basic site of O2− as well as two cations is responsible for the abstraction of H atom from MBDO and UOLs [32]. Since the abstraction of H atom is the key step during dehydration of diols, it is reasonable to correlate the productivity of the catalyst with the number of its basic site. In the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst with HT time of 24 h, the isoprene productivity of 4.2 mmol h−1 g−1 is twenty-one times larger than that the total number of base sites of the catalyst, 0.2 mmol g−1. Therefore, the turnover frequency (TOF) of the Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst in term of its basic site is estimated to be 21 h−1. 3.3 Effect of calcination temperature Fig. 7 illustrates the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst at reaction temperatures of 300 and 400 °C, and the numerical data are listed in Tables S3 and S4, respectively. At 300 °C, Y2Zr2O7-700 and Y2Zr2O7-900 gave the highest MBDO conversion. Nevertheless, isoprene was hardly observed, and the dominant product was UOLs. It is suggested that the dehydration of UOLs to isoprene hardly proceeds at a low reaction temperature of 300 °C. The trend in the catalytic activity at 300 °C was similar to the catalytic activity reported in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO and 1,4-BDO [32,33]. The formation of UOLs was affected by the crystallinity of the oxygen defect fluorite structure [32]: the increment of calcination temperature from 600 to 900 °C improved the crystallinity of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst [34], which favored the formation of UOLs from MBDO. However, a further increment of the calcination temperature from 900 to 1000 °C decreased the MBDO conversion, possibly because the SA was too small to facilitate the dehydration of MBDO to UOLs at a temperature of 300 °C. In contrast, at a high reaction temperature of 400 °C, isoprene was produced as the dominant product along with the UOLs in the dehydration of MBDO. This suggests that the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to isoprene needs high reaction temperatures. Obviously, the MBDO conversion at 400 °C was significantly higher than that at 300 °C; thus, the change in conversion due to the effect of calcination temperature was no longer visible. In order to clarify the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic performance of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst, the dehydration ability was compared. The dehydration ability is defined as the ability of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst to performed two consecutive dehydrations from MBDO to isoprene. The quantitative value of this dehydration ability is expressed by the following equation: D e h y d r a t i o n a b i l i t y = M B D O c o n v . × ( ( 2 × i s o p r e n e s e l e c t . ) + U O L s s e l e c t . ) 10000 According to the above equation, the dehydration ability ranges from 0 to 2. Table S3 reveals that the dehydration ability of Y2Zr2O7 catalysts at a reaction temperature of 300 °C was lower than one due to a low ability for the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts to facilitate the second dehydration of UOLs to isoprene. Meanwhile, the dehydration ability of Y2Zr2O7 catalysts at 400°C was between 1 and 2 (Table S4), indicating that Y2Zr2O7 catalysts had shown the ability to produce isoprene from UOLs formed in the first step dehydration. It is worth noting that the trend of the dehydration ability of Y2Zr2O7 catalysts at 300 and 400 °C was similar. Therefore, it can be assumed that increasing calcination temperature improved the crystallinity of the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts which was favorable for dehydration until the increment of calcination temperature led to a significantly small SA which had negative effect on the dehydration ability of Y2Zr2O7 catalysts. 3.4 Effects of reaction temperature and contact time Fig. 8A shows the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst, while the numerical data are listed in Table S5. The MBDO conversion increased with the increase of reaction temperature up to 350 °C. The conversion slightly decreased upon a further increment of reaction temperature from 375 to 425 °C. Notably, increasing the reaction temperature favored the formation of isoprene as the isoprene selectivity increased with the increment of reaction temperature. In contrast, the selectivity toward UOLs decreased with the increase in reaction temperature. This result suggested that the formation of isoprene from MBDO was a sequential process. It was possible that the dehydration of MBDO produced UOLs as the intermediate product and these UOLs were further dehydrated to isoprene (Scheme 1 ). However, the increment of reaction temperature slightly increased IB selectivity. IB was possibly produced through the decomposition of MBDO [37], which was accelerated by the increment of reaction temperature. Alternatively, our previous reports have suggested that propylene can be readily formed through the decomposition of 3-buten-1-ol [22,32,39]; therefore, IB as the side product might also be produced from 3-methyl-3-buten-1-ol (3M31), but not from 2-methyl-3-buten-2-ol (2M32) and 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol (3M21). To confirm the origin of the IB production, we performed the dehydration of UOLs over Y2Zr2O7-900 catalyst (Table 2 ). The dehydration of 2M32 and 3M21 generated isoprene with high selectivity (entries 1 and 3), whereas the dehydration of 3M31 produced IB with the highest selectivity among all UOLs evaluated (entry 2). In addition to the IB formation, 3M31 dehydration also generated a cyclic ether of 3M31, 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran. Furthermore, the IB formation was accompanied by the formation of methanol without the formation of CO and formaldehyde. This trend was also observed in the dehydration of MBDO over acid catalysts (entries 9 and 10 in Table 1). This phenomenon was possibly due to decomposition of formaldehyde to CO and H2, the methanol could possibly be formed in the hydrogenation of formaldehyde. The dehydration of several UOLs confirmed the assumption that IB was generated from the decomposition of 3M31, while isoprene was the major product in the dehydration of 3M21 and 2M32. Therefore, the formation of 3M31 from MBDO is not favorable for the production of isoprene. In this work, the selectivity of 3M31 was the lowest among UOLs, which led to low production of IB. The low 3M31 selectivity as the route for side reaction also favored the main reaction to generate isoprene, which was shown with the high yield of isoprene. Table 2 clearly indicates the order of the reactivity of UOLs to form isoprene is 3M21>2M32>3M31. Fig. 8B displays the effect of contact time, W/F, on the catalytic activity of the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst at 350 °C, while the numerical data are listed in Table S6. The isoprene yield increased with the increment of contact time, while the yield of UOLs gradually decreased. When the dehydration of MBDO was conducted at W/F = 1.88 h, an isoprene yield of 86.1% was produced at full conversion of MBDO. 3.5 Discussion on the reaction mechanism Table 2 has shown the reactivity of UOLs and saturated alcohols. UOLs are more reactive than their respective saturated alcohols, which is similar to our previous report in the dehydration of C4 saturated and unsaturated alcohols [33]. Because of the higher reactivity of UOLs, it is reasonable to assume that the electron-rich C=C bond might interact with the Lewis acid site of metal cation during the dehydration of UOLs. In fact, olefin is well known to coordinate with metal cations in various reactions [40,41]. We have previously proposed a reaction mechanism of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene over an oxygen defect site of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst [32]: the oxygen defect site exposes cations as Lewis sites and oxygen anions as base sites. In a similar way, we proposed a speculative mechanism of MBDO dehydration to isoprene and its side reaction to produce IB (Scheme 2 ). In the initial step of MBDO dehydration, the OH groups of MBDO were coordinated to the Lewis acid sites of metal cations (Zr4+ or Y3+), while a position-2 hydrogen was coordinated to an O2− site to form tridentate coordination (Scheme 2a). The first dehydration then proceeded via an acid-base concerted mechanism to produce UOLs (Scheme 2a). The second dehydration of UOLs is represented by 3M21 and 3M31 (Scheme 2b and c). Since UOLs contain one OH group and a C=C bond, the interaction between the defect site and UOLs might be weaker than that of MBDO but stronger than their respective saturated alcohol. The position-1 OH group and C=C bond interacted with the Lewis acid sites of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst, while the position-2 H was attached to the O2− site. Following the dehydration via an acid-base concerted mechanism, the isoprene was produced (Scheme 2b and c). In the case of decomposition of 3M31 to form IB; however, after the adsorption of 3M31 on the defect sites of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst, the scission of the C-C bond at positions 1 and 2 occurred to produce IB and formaldehyde (Scheme 2d), which may be decomposed to CO and H2. In addition, it is reasonable that reductive cyclization of 3M31 adsorbed in Scheme 2d can form a major by-product of 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran. It is worth mentioning that further investigation into the adsorption structure is still needed for a more comprehensive reaction mechanism. However, the speculative mechanism in this work, which was derived from the comparative performance of MBDO, UOLs, and saturated alcohols together with the previous work of 1,3-butanediol could provide a basis for determining the reaction mechanism of isoprene production from MBDO. 3.6 Stability of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst Fig. 9 A shows the stability of the Y2Zr2O7 -700, Y2Zr2O7 -800, and Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalysts. Higher calcination temperatures provided higher stability for the TOS of 10 h. We have previously reported that a higher calcination temperature was favorable for the crystal growth of the cubic fluorite structure [34]. As the result, the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst calcined at 900 °C has a better crystal structure which led to higher stability than those of calcination temperatures of 700 and 800 °C. Fig. 9B correlates the yield of isoprene with the TOS at several reaction temperatures over Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst at W/F= 1.88 h. The reaction temperature of 375 °C provided the highest catalytic stability among the reaction temperatures assessed. Despite having a low yield of IB, the reaction temperature of 350 °C gave a lower yield of isoprene than the reaction temperature of 375 °C due to a slower rate of the consecutive UOLs dehydration to isoprene. On the other hand, a high reaction temperature of 400 °C gave the highest rate of MBDO decomposition to IB; therefore, it generated the lowest isoprene yield in the temperature range assessed. Even though the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst showed the highest stability at 375 °C with the highest isoprene yield of 82.4% at a TOS of 10 h, a small decrement of isoprene yield by 8.2 % was still observed, which was caused by the formation of coke with 2.1 wt.% as confirmed by TG analysis depicted in Fig. S5. In summary, the dehydration of MBDO to isoprene successfully proceeded over the Y2Zr2O7 -900 catalyst. This catalytic transformation could be viewed as a more sustainable alternative for isoprene production than the conventional method of naphtha cracking. Furthermore, the utilization of MBDO which could be generated from biomass as the substrate is environmentally friendly since biomass valorization has been recognized to be a carbon neutral process. 4 Conclusion Vapor-phase dehydration of MBDO to produce isoprene was successfully conducted over the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst prepared by hydrothermal aging at 200 °C. During the hydrothermal aging, the crystallization of Y2Zr2O7 procced together with the removal of residual species such as nitrate from the slurry of Y2Zr2O7 precursor. Both the hydrothermal aging time and the following calcination temperature of the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst greatly affected the growth of cubic fluorite crystallite and the acid-base properties, which consecutively affected their catalytic activity for the production of isoprene via dehydration of MBDO. Under the optimum reaction conditions at 375 °C, the highest isoprene yield of 82.4% was achieved at full MBDO conversion at a TOS of 10 h. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol to produce isoprene was investigated over Y2Zr2O7 catalysts prepared by hydrothermal aging at 200 °C with various aging times. Removal of residual species such as nitrate and crystallization of Y2Zr2O7 proceeded during the hydrothermal aging. The X-ray diffraction analysis confirmed the progression of the Y2Zr2O7 crystal growth during hydrothermal aging from 0 to 24 h, with no significant change afterward. The hydrothermal aging time of up to 4 h significantly influenced the acid-base properties of the Y2Zr2O7 catalysts, which consecutively affected their catalytic performance. At a reaction temperature of 375 °C, the conversion of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol and the selectivity to isoprene over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst calcined at 900 °C were 100 and 82.4% at a time on stream of 10 h, respectively. Reaction mechanisms were also proposed in consideration for the results of dehydration of intermediate unsaturated alcohols.
coredata.dc:title: Selective formation of isoprene via dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst
